text: (bright music)

- I am Sarah Storelli, on a
quest to discover the people

behind the cutting edge
innovations across industries
to tell the stories that define them
far more than their titles.
My guest today is Allyson Fryhoff.

Well, thanks so much for being
here with us today, Allyson.
It's such a pleasure to have you.
We're excited to learn more nuggets
from your amazing career.
- Well, thank you, Sarah.
It's an absolute honor and a pleasure.
So thank you.
- Of course, of course.
So I wanna just dive in.
I feel like there's so much to unpack.
So to start off, tell us a little bit

about the humble background,
whether you wanna take us back
to your childhood all the way, or even,
from your collegiate days

and really maybe a little
through that journey
of how you are now here today.

- So I think probably
the most important thread

that runs through my life is
that I wanted to be a teacher.

That idea of being able to
teach, to be able to coach,
to be able to have people grow,

and even now, in their
professional careers
is really important to me.

So I love being able to be a
mentor, a leader, to inspire.
My brother was Down syndrome,
and so my whole life was kind of built

around those with
abilities, as we call it.
And my mom started a non-profit.

So me working with
nonprofits now helps things

come full circle and to know
that the work that we do
is important and has purpose.

- Well, I feel like that could
go so many ways with that,
but I think as a follow-up to that,

I'd almost say you, given
your familial background
in that sense, who along your journey
really has inspired you the most?
- Ah, that's really hard

because there's been so
many, so many people.
But I guess I have to start with my dad
who always said to me, "Do good work.

Do your best, whether
you are the garbage man
or the president of the United States,
always do your best.

And always know that
people recognize that."
And whether I was serving dinner

as a server in restaurants when
I was going through college
and doing that whole thing,

or as I got into a more
professional career,

it's always about really
thinking about how do I show up
and do my best?

How do I bring the best
to my employees as well
and those that I work with?

And that's been really
important to me also.
- That's great, I would even say,

so from that initial kind
hospitality background,
how do you think that has helped serve you
in the role that you are today?
Cause I think that's quite an authentic,
the fact that that relates
to so many of our even viewers watching,
where we all started off.

You know, I even, my first
job, I was in college,
I was a hostess, as well.

And so I'd love to know a
little bit of how you think some

of those hospitality skills
have helped translate
through your journey.

- Absolutely, well, it's good
to hear you were a hostess

because I believe that
everyone should do that
at some point in their lives.
If you ever go out to eat,
you should have some point been a server
or at least have the empathy
for those that are doing that job.

So you learn how to deal
with difficult situations,

you learn how to deal
with difficult people,
but you also learn that feeling
of being able to serve someone
and have done a really good job

and someone enjoyed,
whether it was their meal
or their experience.

And I feel like I've probably
brought that all the way
through my career as well.
- I love that.

And you know, building
on that, even at Amazon,
we live by our leadership principles.
- Absolutely.

- And so I would love to know
which leadership principle
you identify with most.
I know that it may be all of 'em.

It's so hard to choose from,
but if you could choose one

out of all of them, which
one would that be and why?

- I will tell you that
it is customer obsession

because it is that
service to our customers,
and especially the sector that I am in,

which is nonprofits and
nonprofit healthcare.

Each and every one of those
organizations is doing such good
in the world.

And so it is a fantastic
opportunity for us to obsess

about their mission and help
them accomplish their missions.
And we do that every single day.
And so that's probably my favorite.

But as a teacher, I can't
get away from learning,
be curious, which I do every day as well.

Always be learning, always
be asking questions,

always be trying to
understand someone's situation
or their business or their mission
or the programs that they run.
So I could go on as most of us can
because they really do resonate
and we really take them seriously.

We really try to live those
leadership principles.

- I'd really love to know
from your perspective,
especially when you're overseeing,

so many nonprofits and
from healthcare space

and really just across
verticals and industries
of how you really think the power
of tech can be used for good.
- That is what drives me.
That is my purpose.

That's what I wake up
to do every single day,

is to look at what are the
needs of our customers?

What is the experience
that they want to create?
I see, and have such an opportunity to see
so many great ways where technology

is making the world
actually a better place.

Certainly understand that's
not how it's always used,
but that's what I get to see
and that's what I get to talk about,

and that's the teams
that I get to work with,

is we think every day is
how is this technology
going to help to create better experiences
for those who are doing good in the world?
My mom actually started a nonprofit,

and I would come and help
her as I, we all volunteered,
we all did so many things,

and there'd be a printer that
wasn't working, for instance,

and it it was broken down and
they'd be fussing with it.

And it would take so much
time and I would say,
"Mom, I'm just gonna buy you a printer.
Let me just get you."
"Oh, no, no, no. We're nonprofits.
We don't deserve new printers.
We have to make do."

And I said, "Okay, you are
spending so much time with this,
and you could be doing so much more

serving your beneficiaries,
being out in the community.

So I think about that
a lot when I'm working

with our nonprofits who are
doing amazing, innovative things
with our technology.
But there's often a lot of conversations

around this really is
a return on investment
for your programs, for your beneficiaries.

I get very excited, as you
can tell, when I can think
about the innovative ways
that they can use AWS technology.

- Even from that standpoint,
saying for any of nonprofits
that may be watching,
to that extent how, what other advice
would you give them, maybe to be open

to the idea of exploring
leveraging technology

to really help advance
their purpose and mission?

- Well, Sarah, I think you
said the word, be open.

Be open to the conversation
and the discussion
because there's so much that can be done,
and we often have people think about,
think about your own consumer experience.
Think about getting a package from Amazon.

Thinking about now,
it's easy to return it.
Think about all the little things
that make that a delightful experience.

We think about that
every day at AWS as well.

Think about how you would
like that experience to be,
and then talk to us (laughs)
because we think that we can help.

We think that we truly can
help with the technology
to help you meet those mission goals.
- That's great.
Everyone, take note, who's listening.

Another question I have
for you is, obviously,

you've had a fantastic
trajectory and career overall.

And I think that really
is a true testament

to your personal beliefs and
really around your empathy.

And so I think, you know,
being a woman in leadership,

and really making that
climb, I'd love to hear

even just a little bit
about your experience,
even any tips, for those who are watching
as well, other rising stars,

or women who are even just
starting out in their careers
or looking to reenter the workforce.

Maybe just explore a little
bit of how important it
has been to you on your journey

about not only being
a woman in leadership,

but even finding other mentors
who are women in leadership.

- It's so interesting because
when I started in technology,
I won't tell you how many years ago,
right in Silicon Valley,

it was early, early early
days of Silicon Valley.
There was one woman,

and I won't mention
her name at this point,
but that really made a difference,

pushed me farther than I
thought I could go myself.

And I think I learned
a lot from her in that.
And she kind of pulled me into a situation

was like, "Well, we're
gonna do a startup company

and you're gonna have
sales and partnerships
and this and that."
And then I remember thinking, "Okay,
I haven't really done all of that before,
but let's go try to do that.
And she believed in me.
And so now, so much of my career
over the last number of years

has been in that broader
perspective of a business.
And so I like to think about that a lot

as, okay, how do I push
the next generation

to believe in themselves to
take that next step, to be bold

to ask for that job, to
ask for that promotion,
to take on that additional responsibility
because they can, and I know they can.

And very often, other
people can see that in us
before we even see it.

And so I would say for
women, be bold. (laughs)

I often say be bold, be curious
about what else you can do
and look for those other opportunities.

And then my third one that I
always come back to is be kind.

Because while you're
doing all of those things,

helping others come with
you is so, so important.
Don't be afraid when there's other
really smart women around you.

Bring them along, talk
to them, learn from them.

And you talked about some of
the those that are younger

in their career, much
smarter than I am, always.
And I learn so much from them.

And so I think that's the
other thing to remember
that everyone has something to give,
and everyone has something to learn.
And so it's usually a two-way relationship

when you're working as
a mentor or a mentee.
And I try to remember that as well.
- That's fantastic.
Well, I would thank you
so much for your time today, Allyson.

It's just been so wonderful
having this conversation

and in hearing a glimpse
into your journey,
and some really helpful nuggets
for the audience listening in.

And we're excited to continue
to see all the amazing

innovations that you make,
and looking forward to seeing
more of your journey.
So thank you, once again.
- Thank you. Thank you so much, Sarah.
- Thanks so much.
(bright music)
